content: Negotiating parties of the proposed Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement (ACTA) have until May 1, 2013, to sign the agreement. The ACTA will enter into force after the sixth instrument of ratification is deposited. Mexico signed the ACTA on July 11, 2012, requiring ratification in the Mexican Congress. The European Parliament voted against the ACTA on July 4, 2012, preventing the EU and its member states from joining. Several EU member states suspended or did not initiate domestic adoption of the ACTA in early 2012 due to protests by Internet free speech advocates. On January 25, 2012, the European Union and 22 member states signed the ACTA, with five member states not signing due to procedural issues. The proposed Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement (ACTA) involves countries like the United States, Australia, Canada, the European Union, Japan, South Korea, Mexico, and others. Negotiations for the ACTA concluded in October 2010 after nearly three years. The agreement aims to combat intellectual property rights infringement and build on existing standards. Participants are preparing to sign the Agreement soon and work cooperatively towards its prompt entry into force. The Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement (ACTA) was negotiated outside of the WTO and focuses on enforcing trademarks and copyrights. It establishes a legal framework for intellectual property rights enforcement, including civil, border, and criminal measures for trademark counterfeiting and copyright piracy. The agreement also promotes international cooperation and best practices. The ACTA negotiation concluded in October 2010 after nearly three years. The initial provisions chapter of the ACTA discusses the nature and scope of the agreement, its relationship to existing agreements, provisions on privacy and disclosure of information, and definitions of terms used in the agreement. It states that the ACTA shall not derogate from each Party's obligations under existing agreements, provides flexibility for each Party to implement more extensive IPR enforcement, and notes that the objectives and principles of the TRIPS Agreement apply to the ACTA. The Agreement under ACTA does not mandate applying obligations to intellectual property not protected under domestic laws. It includes general obligations for enforcement, civil enforcement, border measures, criminal enforcement, and enforcement in the digital environment. Parties are committed to effective IPR enforcement, avoiding trade barriers, and fair treatment. Proportionality in enforcement is required, considering seriousness of infringement and applicable measures. Civil enforcement mandates each Party to establish civil judicial procedures for IPR. The civil enforcement section of the Agreement under ACTA mandates each Party to provide judicial authorities with the power to issue injunctions, award damages to right holders, recover costs and attorneys' fees, order the destruction of infringing goods, and implement provisional measures to prevent infringement. The civil enforcement section of the Agreement under ACTA mandates each Party to provide judicial authorities with the power to issue injunctions, award damages to right holders, recover costs and attorneys' fees, order the destruction of infringing goods, and implement provisional measures, such as seizures, to prevent infringement. Additionally, the border measures section focuses on effective border enforcement of intellectual property rights without discrimination and barriers to legitimate trade. Each Party is required to adopt or maintain procedures for customs authorities to suspend the release of suspect goods and may request customs authorities to do so in certain situations. The Agreement under ACTA mandates each Party to provide procedures for customs authorities to suspend the release of suspect goods and may request customs authorities to do so in certain situations. The criminal enforcement section requires each Party to provide for criminal procedures and penalties in cases of willful trademark counterfeiting or copyright piracy on a commercial scale. The Agreement under ACTA mandates each Party to provide penalties for willful trademark counterfeiting or copyright piracy on a commercial scale, including imprisonment and monetary fines. It also requires authorities to seize suspected counterfeit goods and materials, order forfeiture or destruction of infringing goods, and seize assets derived from infringing activities. The digital enforcement section of the ACTA agreement mandates each Party to ensure effective enforcement against IPR infringement in the digital environment, while preserving freedom of expression and privacy. The ACTA agreement mandates each Party to ensure effective enforcement against IPR infringement in the digital environment, while preserving fundamental principles of freedom of expression, fair process, and privacy. Parties may order online service providers to disclose identifying information related to alleged infringement. Legal protection and remedies against circumvention of technological measures are required, along with the promotion of enforcement expertise and data collection. The USTR leads ACTA negotiations for U.S. trade agreements, consulting various agencies and stakeholders. The agreement was negotiated as an executive agreement, not requiring congressional approval unless it impacts U.S. law. The USTR ensured consistency with existing U.S. law during negotiations. The USTR states that ACTA is consistent with U.S. law, including copyright, patent, and trademark laws. It does not require new legislation from Congress for implementation. The congressional role in ACTA is rooted in the U.S. Constitution, as it concerns foreign commerce and intellectual property rights. Congress has played an oversight and consultative role during the ACTA negotiation process and can engage in oversight of its implementation. The use of an executive agreement for ACTA negotiations may be a departure from past approaches to international trade negotiations on intellectual property rights. The United States has advanced IPR goals internationally through trade agreements, facing concerns about rising global IPR infringement. High costs of research and development in IPR-based industries contrast with low risks and high profits of infringement. Technologies like digital media have increased piracy, aided by growing Internet usage. Inadequate penalties in some countries fail to deter counterfeiting and piracy, making international IPR protection and enforcement a major issue. The United States emphasizes the importance of protecting intellectual property rights (IPR) internationally due to its significance to the economy and the negative consequences of counterfeiting and piracy. Economic, health and safety, and security reasons are cited as motivations for negotiating the Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement (ACTA). Adequate IPR protection is crucial for promoting innovation and competitiveness in industries. Advocates of strong international IPR regime argue that counterfeiting and piracy cause significant revenue and trade losses for legitimate industries. The difficulty in quantifying these losses is due to the secretive and illicit nature of IPR infringement, especially with digital media being distributed online. Companies may also be hesitant to disclose information about IPR infringement issues with their products. Some question the commercial rationale for the ACTA, as estimates for losses from IPR infringement are often industry-generated. Analysts doubt that sales of pirated goods directly result in revenue losses for legitimate firms, as some consumers may not purchase the legitimate version. Advocates of civil liberties argue that government discussions on ACTA should consider the economic benefits of exceptions like "fair use" in copyright law. Some public interest groups argue that IPR protection may favor private rights over broader economic and social welfare. Critics suggest unbalanced IPR rules could hinder information flow. Another reason for U.S. involvement in ACTA is health and safety concerns related to counterfeiting and piracy, with advocates warning about substandard counterfeit products. Public health advocates caution against conflating counterfeiting with health risks, emphasizing the importance of legitimate goods. Some express concern that increasing IPR protection may hinder access to affordable medicines. U.S. involvement in the ACTA also focuses on security concerns related to counterfeiting and piracy, which may be linked to organized crime syndicates engaging in various illicit activities. The United States pursues IPR objectives through various trade policy mechanisms, including multilaterally through the WTO, regionally and bilaterally through FTAs, and domestically through U.S. trade laws. The ACTA aims to enhance the commitments of the TRIPS Agreement and address concerns about counterfeiting and piracy linked to organized crime syndicates. The United States supports the negotiation of the ACTA to address gaps in the TRIPS Agreement regarding IPR challenges, especially in new technologies and digital piracy. The advancement of trade negotiations in multilateral venues has stalled in recent years, with the WTO Doha Round and WIPO global patent agenda at a standstill.
